parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>False. There is no CMF number present in the provided post information.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>False. While the post is clearly related to the Romanian parliamentary elections and targets the Hungarian minority, it does not explicitly mention any specific candidate by name or implicitly endorse a particular candidate. The call to vote is general, urging the Hungarian community to vote to protect their interests.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>True. The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform, and its message is clearly intended to reach a wide audience within the Hungarian community in Romania. The language used ("we," "us," "our") suggests a collective appeal.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>True. The primary objective of the post is to encourage the Hungarian minority in Romania to vote in the parliamentary elections. The message highlights the perceived threat to their interests and frames voting as a means of self-preservation.  While not explicitly endorsing a specific candidate, the post strongly implies that voting is crucial for the Hungarian community's well-being, thus indirectly influencing voting behavior.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>False. The post lacks the objectivity and neutrality expected of journalistic content. It presents a biased perspective, emphasizing the perceived threat to the Hungarian community and urging them to vote without providing balanced information or alternative viewpoints. The emotional appeal and call to action are not characteristic of journalistic reporting.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>False. The post does not express a personal opinion; instead, it presents a political message aimed at mobilizing a specific segment of the electorate. The language used is not personal but rather collective and appeals to shared identity and concerns.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>1133970618342201</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post, while not explicitly mentioning any candidate, constitutes electoral propaganda due to its clear intention to influence voting behavior within a specific community. It uses emotional appeals and frames voting as a crucial action for self-preservation, thereby indirectly promoting a particular outcome in the elections. The paid nature of the Facebook advertisement further strengthens its classification as electoral propaganda.  The fact that it targets a specific ethnic group and uses strong emotional language to encourage voting makes it highly likely to influence the election.  However, the lack of explicit endorsement of a specific candidate might be considered a mitigating factor, depending on the court's interpretation.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>TRUE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>RMDSZ</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
RMDSZ Bihar Megye, pentru încălcarea articolului 98 t) din LEGEA nr. 208 din 20 iulie 2015, prin publicarea unei reclame plătite pe Facebook după ora 18:00 pe 23.11.2024, cu ID-ul postării 1133970618342201, care, deși nu menționează explicit un candidat, constituie propagandă electorală prin apelul emoțional la comunitatea maghiară din România, îndemnându-i să voteze pentru a-și proteja interesele.  Reclama, cu o cheltuială de sub 100 RON, a atins între 2000 și 3000 de impresii și o estimare a audienței de 100.000 - 500.000 de persoane, având ca efect electoral mobilizarea electoratului maghiar.  Textul reclamei, "Veszélyben vagyunk! (...) Rajtad múlik (...) Csak együtt tudjuk megvédeni...",  constituie un apel direct la acțiune, influențând votul fără a respecta neutralitatea necesară.  Contactul este biharmegye@rmdsz.ro și +40771314601.
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
